hotspots.label: Blue Ink Plume
hotspots.fact: This blue cloud-like formation is created when ink diffuses, or spreads out, through water. Diffusion happens when particles move from areas where there are lots of them to areas where there are fewer of them, creating beautiful swirling patterns!

hotspots.label: Clear Water Below
hotspots.fact: The bottom of the jar shows water that hasn't mixed with the ink yet. Over time, the blue ink will continue to spread throughout all the water through a process called diffusion, eventually turning the entire jar blue.

hotspots.label: Jar Opening
hotspots.fact: This closed jar traps the water and ink together, allowing us to observe diffusion safely. If the jar were open, air currents could disturb the experiment and make the ink spread unevenly.

hotspots.label: Ink-Water Boundary
hotspots.fact: You can see where the dark blue ink meets the clear water - this is the diffusion boundary. Over time, this fuzzy line will disappear as the ink and water molecules mix together completely, demonstrating how particles move randomly.
